Package gdi.game

Class World

java.lang.Object
gdi.game.World
Direct Known Subclasses:
gdi.game.ImageWorld
public class World extends Object
The base class of a game. A World provides the infrastructure to handle all game related tasks and most importantly the game-loop (see run()). It also opens a window that should be used as a canvas and provides several methods to inject code into the various stages of the game-loop (the list represents the order you can expect those methods to fire:
  • setupWindow()
  • setupWorld()
  • willShowWorld()
  • willRunWorld()
  • didRunWorld()
  • printStatistics(int, int, int, double)
  • update(double, double)
  • render(double)
  • drawWorldInWindow(Graphics)
  • windowSizeChangedTo(int, int)

Depending on how the world was created (see World(Settings)) the game-loop may run in its own thread.

In the most basic case, you set up and run a world like this: 

 {
     World w = new World();
     w.run();
 }
Version:
1.0
Author:
frank

    • World

      public World(gdi.game.Settings settings, boolean threaded)
      Creates a new game world. The threading behaviour is determined by the value of the threaded parameter.

      The world will not run after it is created, giving you the opportunity to do some setup work before the actual game-loop is started.

      The world keeps track of the gameTime, which is set to zero when it is created and just before the game-loop is executed. So beware that the time before running the world and after is not in sync!

      The constructor calls the following methods in the given sequence:

      1. setupWindow()
      Parameters:
      settings - the world settings you want to use
      threaded - true if the game-loop should run in its own thread.
      See Also:
      • run()

      Enables the test mode of the world (will not create a UI but render in the background)

      public boolean areUpdatesPaused()
      Test whether or not update(double, double)-calls are currently paused.
      Returns:
      true if no update(double, double)-calls are generated
      See Also:
      • setUpdatesPaused(boolean)

    • setUpdatesPaused

      public void setUpdatesPaused(boolean updatesPaused)
      Allows you to suppress update(double, double)-calls. While paused, the game time will not progress. However, the system will continue to call render(double)
      Parameters:
      updatesPaused - true if no update(double, double)-calls should be generated

    • getSettings

      public final gdi.game.Settings getSettings()
      Returns the settings associated with this world.
      Returns:
      The world was created using those settings

    • getWindow

      public final gdi.util.UI.WindowInterface getWindow()
      Returns an Instance of the window that was created in setupWindow(). This window provides the Graphics canvas in drawWorldInWindow(Graphics). The window-Attribute is never changed during the lifetime of the world.
      Returns:
      the stored window
      See Also:
      • drawWorldInWindow(Graphics)
      • setupWindow()

    • queueEvent

      public void queueEvent(gdi.game.events.UserEvent event)
      Queues a custom event. The queued event will be executed on the next iteration of the game-loop on its respective thread
      Parameters:
      event - The event that should get queue

    • stop

      public final void stop()
      Stops the game-loop. The loop is not halted synchronously but as fast as possible.

    • isRunning

      public final boolean isRunning()
      Checks weather or not the game-loop is currently running
      Returns:
      true when the loop is running or about to start, false when it stopped or will stop after the next loop.

    • setSleepsInLoop

      public final void setSleepsInLoop(boolean val)
      Defines if the game-loop sleeps while waiting for the next cycle. See runIntern(int, int) for details.
      Parameters:
      val - true if the loop should sleep.
      See Also:
      • runIntern(int, int)
      • isSleepingInLoop()

    • isSleepingInLoop

      public final boolean isSleepingInLoop()
      Check if the run-loop is currently configured to sleep while waiting or not. You can change the behaviour at any time, even after the game-loop was started.
      Returns:
      true when the world is configured to sleep while waiting for the next scheduled render(double) or update(double, double) call.
      See Also:
      • runIntern(int, int)
      • setSleepsInLoop(boolean)

    • setRunsInThread

      public final void setRunsInThread(boolean val) throws gdi.game.InvalidStateException
      Changes the threading behaviour of the World. This Method will throw an InvalidStateException when it is called while the game-loop is running.
      Parameters:
      val - true if you want the game-loop to run in a separate thread. Otherwise the loop runs on the Thread run() is called from.
      Throws:
      gdi.game.InvalidStateException - This exception is thrown when you try to change the state while the game-loop is running.
      See Also:
      • run()
      • isRunningInThread()

    • isRunningInThread

      public final boolean isRunningInThread()
      Check if the game-loop is configured to run in a separate thread
      Returns:
      true if a new thread is/was created
      See Also:
      • setRunsInThread(boolean)

    • setNeedsDisplay

      public final void setNeedsDisplay()
      Notifies the window that its content was changed. This forces the window to schedule a repaint as soon as possible.

    • getTime

      public final double getTime()
      Returns the current game time in seconds.

      Caution: The time before running the world and after is not in sync! Starting the game-loop will always reset the time to zero!

      Returns:
      Number of seconds that passed since the game-loop was started

    • increaseTime

      public final void increaseTime(double time)
      Increases the game time by the specified amount.
      Parameters:
      time - The time (in seconds) the game time should progress. The method will use the absolute value.

    • run

      public void run()
      Starts the game-loop. For more details about the loop itself, please refer to runIntern(int, int). Before starting the loop the following tasks are performed in the given order:
      • Reset the game time (resetReferenceTime())
      • Call the setupWorld()-method
      • Call render(double) twice with a deltaTime of 0. This is done to ensure that all double-buffered storages are initialized correctly
      • Call the willShowWorld()-method
      • Present the Window to the user
      • Call the willRunWorld()-method
      • Start the actual game-loop (either threaded or not depending on the value returned by isRunningInThread()) by calling runIntern(int, int).
      • Call the didRunWorld()-method

      When the game-loop is started it will periodically generate calls to render(double) and update(double, double). The maximum number of calls to render(double) and update(double, double) is set to 30Hz. If you need more control over the update rates, you can use run(int) or run(int, int).

      See Also:
      • run(int)
      • run(int, int)

    • run

      public final void run(int fps)
      Starts the game-loop and lets you specify rate for render(double) and update(double, double) calls.

      For details on starting the game-loop, please refer to run()

      Parameters:
      fps - The maximum rate of calls to render(double) and update(double, double) per second
      See Also:
      • run()
      • run(int, int)

    • run

      public final void run(int renderFPS, int updateFPS)
      Starts the game-loop and lets you specify an individual rate for render(double) and update(double, double) calls.

      For details on starting the game-loop, please refer to run()

      Parameters:
      renderFPS - The maximum rate for render(double)-calls per second
      updateFPS - The maximum rate for update(double, double)-calls per second
      See Also:
      • run()
      • run(int)

    • getRenderFPS

      public double getRenderFPS()
      The maximum rate for render(double)-calls per second
      Returns:
      The value you specified for the frame rate when you last called run(int, int) or 0 if the loop was not yet started

    • getUpdateFPS

      public double getUpdateFPS()
      The maximum rate for update(double, double)-calls per second
      Returns:
      The value you specified for the frame rate when you last called run(int, int) or 0 if the loop was not yet started
